ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Optical, photo-acoustic and electrical switching studies of amorphous GeS2 thin films

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Department of Instrumentation and Applied Physics

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: This paper reports optical, photo-acoustic and electrical switching investigations of GeS2 amorphous thin films of different thicknesses, deposited on glass substrates in vacuum. The Tauc parameter (B 1/2) and Urbach energy (E U) have been determined from the transmittance spectra, to understand the changes in structural disorder; it is found that B 1/2 increases whereas E U decreases as the thickness of the films increases. Based on the results, it is suggested that bond re-arrangement, i.e. transformation from homopolar bonds to heteropolar bonds, takes place with increase in thickness. The thermal diffusivity values of GeS2 thin films also show the presence of a chemically ordered network in the GeS2 thin films. Further, it is found that these films exhibit memory-type electrical switching. The observed variation in the switching voltages has been understood on the basis of increase in chemical order.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Amorphous chalcogenides find applications in a variety of fields including phase-change memories, infrared optics, xerography etc. Studies of electrical, optical and thermal properties help us in identifying suitable samples for different applications. In particular, electrical switching studies of chalcogenide glasses have attracted intense investigations in recent times [1]. There are studies of electrical, switching, thermal, optical and high-pressure behaviours of chalcogenide glassy semiconductors [2â5]. Several sulphur-based glasses such as Ge46S54, GeS, As2S3 etc. have been reported to exhibit interesting electrical properties including electrical switching [6â8]. Particularly, sulphur-rich vacuum-evaporated Ge46S54 thin films of thickness ranging from 123 to 370Â nm have been found to exhibit memory-type electrical switching [6].

Electrical switching exhibited by chalcogenide glasses [9] is classified into reversible (threshold) and irreversible (memory) types of switching. While there is a school of thought suggesting that switching is essentially a thermal effect due to the formation of a hot filament in the electrode region [10], there are also reports which suggest that switching is an entirely electronic phenomenon [11]. It is now widely accepted that the initiation of switching in both threshold- and memory-type glasses is primarily electronic in nature and it occurs when the charged defect states are filled up by the field-injected charge carriers; however, additional thermal effects come into play in memory materials which result in the formation of a conducting crystalline channel between the electrodesÂ [12].

The thermal properties like glass formability and thermal diffusivity are important factors for selecting a chalcogenide glass for phase change memory application based on the phenomenon of electrical switching [13]. In particular, thermal diffusivity is an important parameter, as it determines the rate of periodic or transient heat propagation through a medium. The determination of thermal diffusivity is often necessary because of its major role in those phenomena controlled by thermal conduction, such as memory switching [14]. Generally, photo-acoustic spectroscopy (PAS) is used to estimate the thermal diffusivity of bulk and thin-film chalcogenides [15, 16]. It is also found that there is a good correlation between thermal diffusivity and switching behaviour of chalcogenide glasses; chalcogenide glasses which have higher thermal diffusivity normally exhibit threshold-type electrical switching and those which have lower thermal diffusivity show memory behaviour [17]. In a similar way, there is a correlation between optical properties and electrical switching behaviour of amorphous and glassy chalcogenides.

In this work, thermal diffusivity measurements have been undertaken on amorphous GeS2 thin films, using photo-acoustic spectroscopy. Further, studies of optical properties and electrical switching were carried out to understand the thickness-dependent properties of these thin films. Particularly, the Urbach energy and the Tauc parameter are estimated, which provide a better understanding of the mechanism of Urbach tail width [18] and disorder effects [19].

Section1.Heading: Experimental details
Section1.Para: Bulk GeS2 glass was prepared from a stoichiometric mixture of high-purity elements (99.999Â % HiMedia, India). The mixture was placed in a quartz ampoule and sealed under a vacuum of 10â5Â Torr. The ampoule was heated to 1000Â Â°C and kept for 36Â h inside a rotating furnace in order to ensure homogeneity of the melt. Bulk glassy ingots were obtained by quenching the ampoule in ice-cold water mixed with NaOH.

Amorphous GeS2 thin films were deposited from bulk glassy ingots, at a rate of 5Â Ã /s, by resistive evaporation, on cleaned glass substrates held at room temperature under a vacuum of 2Ã10â5Â Torr. Molybdenum boats were used for the evaporation of the material in a vacuum-deposition unit (HINDHIVAC 12A4D) attached to a quartz crystal thickness monitor. The thin films deposited on the glass substrates are of different thicknesses, namely 140, 310, 465, 623 and 781Â nm, respectively. The thicknesses of the films were also confirmed using a surface roughness tester (SJ-210, Mitutoyo) and the average error bar was found to be Â±3Â %. For each thickness, two glass plates were deposited, one for switching studies using suitable masks and the other glass plate for various characterizations. The substrates were kept at a distance of 10Â cm vertically above the source. During each deposition, the bulk material taken in the boat was completely evaporated at a fast rate so that no residual alloy remained from the previous deposition. It is worth mentioning here that each time fresh pieces of the alloy were used for the deposition of different thin films. This procedure is necessary to ensure homogeneity due to preferential evaporation of one of the components, the volatile sulphur.

X-ray diffraction (XRD) studies were carried out using an XâPert PRO X-ray diffractometer with CuK Î± radiation (Î»=1.54Â Ã ). The elemental compositions of these glasses were analyzed in a high-resolution scanning electron microscope (SEM-FEI Quanta FEG 200) equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) facility. The optical transmittance was obtained using a computerised double-beam UV-visible spectrophotometer (Techcomp model 2301) in the wavelength range from 300 to 1100Â nm at room temperature.

For switching devices, thin films were coated in a sandwich geometry using suitable masks with Al of thickness 100Â nm as top and bottom electrodes (AlâGeS2âAl) (Fig.Â 1). The active area of the thin-film switching devices was about 5 mmÃ5 mm. The electrical switching behaviour was studied by recording the currentâvoltage (IâV) characteristics using a Keithley source meter (model 2410) controlled by LabVIEW (National Instruments).
Fig.Â 1
Sandwiched device structure for memory switching analysis

For the PAS study, a 450 W Xe lamp (Horiba Jobin Yvon, USA) was used as the source; the schematic of the photo-acoustic setup used is shown in Fig.Â 2. The sample (filmÂ + substrate) was placed inside the photo-acoustic (PA) cell; the microphone was placed very close to the sample. To produce modulated light, a mechanical chopper (C-995, Tetrahertz Technologies Inc., USA) was used with the source. The photo-acoustic signal from the microphone wass fed to a lock-in amplifier (SR830 DSP, Stanford Research, USA). The photo-acoustic spectrometer had been indigenously integrated and automated with a PC for fast data acquisition and better accuracy.
Fig.Â 2
Schematic diagram of the photo-acoustic spectrometer

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
FigureÂ 3 shows the XRD patterns of the as-deposited GeS2 thin films of different thicknesses. This figure indicates that there is no evidence of sharp X-ray peaks, confirming the amorphous nature of the prepared films. The analysis of the EDX spectrum given in TableÂ 1 reveals that the composition of GeS2 films of 623Â nm is close to stoichiometry. The films of other thicknesses are slightly germanium rich.

Section2.Heading: Optical band gap
Section2.Para:
FigureÂ 4 shows the transmittance spectra of as-deposited GeS2 thin films. The film of thickness 140Â nm does not show any interference pattern, whereas the number of interference fringes increases with increase of thickness from 310 to 781Â nm. The film of 781Â nm thickness shows an interference pattern with maxima at 605, 737 and 965Â nm, while the corresponding minima are obtained at 658 and 832Â nm, respectively. The interference patterns arise when the light is reflected from the top surface of the film and the bottom of the film, which confirms the formation of smooth and uniform films [20]. The number of interference fringes also increases with increase in thickness.
Fig.Â 4
Transmittance spectra for GeS2 thin films of various thicknesses

The plot of absorption coefficient (Î±) versus wavelength can be subdivided into two regions, namely the Tauc and Urbach regions corresponding to Î±>104Â cmâ1 and Î±<104Â cmâ1, respectively [21]. In the Tauc region the optical band gap can be determined by the relation [22] 1
$$ (\alpha h \upsilon)^{\frac{1}{2}} = B^{\frac{1}{2}} (h\upsilon - E_{\mathrm{Tauc}} ), $$ where B 1/2 is the Tauc parameter, E Tauc is the Tauc band gap and hÏ is the incident photon energy. FigureÂ 5 shows the plot of (Î±hÏ )1/2 versus photon energy (hÏ ). The Tauc band gap is obtained by extrapolating the linear portion of this curve to the x-axis (Tauc extrapolation) [23] and the Tauc parameter (B 1/2) is determined from the slope; they are given in TableÂ 2. The band gap of 2.483(1)Â eV obtained for the sample of thickness 140Â nm is in good agreement with the literature values [24]. From TableÂ 2 it is found that the band gap energy decreases with increase in thickness for GeS2 thin films. The decrease in optical band gap can be explained by using the âdensity of states modelâ proposed by Mott and Davis [25], which suggests that the width of the localized states near the mobility edges is dependent on the degree of disorder and defects present in the amorphous structure. It is well understood that unsaturated (homopolar) bonds along with some saturated (heteropolar) bonds are produced during the deposition of amorphous films [26]. These unsaturated bonds are also responsible for the creation of defects in the film with low thickness of about 140Â nm, which produce localized states in amorphous systems [21]. Therefore, the observed decrease in optical band gap with increase in the thickness in the present GeS2 amorphous thin films may be due to the presence of a high concentration of localized states in the band structure. In an amorphous or structurally disordered film, the imperfection causes the bands of localized states to broaden, and consequently a band gap reduction may occur with increase in thickness due to the Urbach edge [27].
Fig.Â 5
Tauc extrapolation plot for GeS2 thin films of various thicknesses

Section2.Heading: Thickness dependence of B 1/2 and E U
Section2.Para:
In the low-absorption region (Î±<104Â cmâ1), known as the Urbach edge region [28], the absorption coefficient is governed by 2
$$ \alpha = \alpha_{0} \exp \biggl(\frac{hv}{E_{\mathrm{U}}} \biggr). $$

Here, the Urbach edge energy E U characterizes the slope of this region. The value of E U can be calculated from the inverse of the slope of the straight line plotted between ln(Î±) versus photon energy, which gives the width of the tails of the localized states into the gap at band edges [29]; TableÂ 2 gives the values of the optical parameters obtained, indicating that as the thickness increases, B 1/2 increases and E U decreases.

The B 1/2 value for the film of 140Â nm is 175 (cmâ1/2âeVâ1/2) and that for the film of 781Â nm is 266 (cmâ1/2âeVâ1/2). The increase in the Tauc parameter with increase in thickness provides a clue that the level of ordering in oriented chains is higher when the film thickness is increased. The Tauc parameter increases monotonically with thickness, which indicates that the thicker the film, the smaller the effect of the disorder. Here, the disorder refers to the electronic states within the material as compared to the irregularities in the atomic arrangement [30]. The increase in film thickness leads to an increased ordering in oriented chains [19]. The Urbach energies found for the 140 and 781Â nm films are 0.648 and 0.433Â eV, respectively. This relatively high value of E U for the lower thickness films can be attributed to the presence of homopolar bonds like GeâGe and SâS [31]. Materials with larger Urbach energy would have a greater tendency to convert weak bonds into defects [32]. When the thickness increases from 140 to 781Â nm, the heteropolar bonds like GeâS (53.5Â kcal/mol) are expected to form in large numbers due to the greater bond strength compared to those of GeâGe (37.6Â kcal/mol) and SâS (50.90Â kcal/mol) [33, 34]. It is seen from TableÂ 2 that there is a decrease in E U with increase in thickness due to greater structural stability of the glassy system. The film of thickness 781Â nm shows a higher value of B 1/2 and a lower value of E U, which clearly indicate that the higher thickness film is found to be more ordered [35]. Similar decreases in E g and E U with increase in thickness have been reported by El-Naggar for Si thin filmsÂ [36].

Section2.Heading: Thermal diffusivity
Section2.Para:
FigureÂ 6aâe show the plot of photo-acoustic (PA) signal versus the square root of modulation frequency for GeS2 thin films of various thicknesses. All figures show a curvature, which indicates the evidence of thermo-elastic bending. As the RosencwaigâGersho theory [37] is valid for the thermally thick regime, the curves have been fitted to the higher modulation frequency region to obtain the thermal diffusivity and the values are also given in TableÂ 2.
Fig.Â 6
Thermal diffusivity for GeS2 thin films of thickness (a)Â 140Â nm, (b)Â 310Â nm, (c)Â 465Â nm, (d)Â 623Â nm and (e)Â 781Â nm

As the thickness of GeS2 thin films increases from 140 to 781Â nm, the thermal diffusivity is also found to increase from 0.095Ã10â9 to 3.529Ã10â9Â m2/s. In the PAS technique, the thin-film sample absorbs light and generates photo-carriers. These excess photo-carriers diffuse through the sample and generate heat. The PA signal is mainly dependent on this heat generation. It is well known that the thermal conductivity of a solid is due to the heat transport by both phonons and carriers [38]. The increase in thermal diffusivity with thickness may be attributed to the changes in the short-range order taking place in the amorphous network with the increase in the concentration of Ge. As the concentration of Ge atoms increases with thickness, the sulphur-atom chains become increasingly cross linked by Ge atoms. As a result, a stable structure consisting of GeS4 tetrahedral units is formed for the highly ordered film of 781Â nm with GeâS bonds having higher bond energy [14]. Usually, chalcogenide glasses which have a higher thermal diffusivity exhibit threshold-type electrical switching and those which have a lower thermal diffusivity show memory behaviour. The comparatively lower thermal diffusivity value of GeS2 glasses is consistent with their memory behaviourÂ [17].

Section2.Heading: Memory-type electrical switching
Section2.Para:
The currentâvoltage (IâV) characteristics of representative GeS2 thin films of thickness 310 and 465Â nm are shown in Fig.Â 7a andÂ b. In Fig.Â 7a, it can be seen that with an increase in current there is a small change in voltage, which represents the high-resistance OFF state of the device (the region âoaâ of the curve). At point (a), there is a sudden drop in voltage and the switching occurs along the load line (ab), leading to the ON state. As the transition to the ON state is very fast, no data points can be observed in this range (ab). Any further increase in the applied current does not produce any significant increase in the potential drop across the sample (part (bc) of the curve representing the ON state with low resistance). On decreasing the applied current, the voltage decreases to zero value along the path (co) of the curve. The observed behaviour is a typical IâV characteristic for a memory switch.
Fig.Â 7
IâV characteristic curves for GeS2 thin films of thickness (a)Â 310Â nm and (b)Â 465Â nm

It is seen from Fig.Â 7 that the film exhibits three states, namely the OFF state with high resistance, a current-controlled negative-resistance (CCNA) state above the threshold voltage (V T) and the ON state with low resistance. Here, the negative-resistance region leads to the low-resistance ON state and once the device becomes latched to the ON state, it does not revert back to the initial high-resistance state even if the applied current is reduced to zero. This clearly indicates that GeS2 thin films exhibit memory switching behaviour. A similar memory type of switching behaviour has been seen in GeâTeâSe and GeâTeâSn thin-film samples also [39, 40]. It is also found that samples of thicknesses 140 and 623Â nm do not exhibit switching and exhibited sparking at the electrode region. Similar behaviour of sparking during switching has been reported earlier in Ge x Te100âx and Si x Te100âx amorphous films [41] also. The observed behaviour has been attributed to an abrupt increase in current, which causes an adiabatic heating of the active material to near-melting temperatures. This causes the partial splashing of the active material in the switched zone, which quickly resolidifies in the amorphous state [41]. For the films of thickness 310, 465 and 781Â nm, the IâV characteristics are measured at different points throughout the surface of the film, and the mean value of the threshold voltage (V T) has been found as 10.126, 7.483 and 0.048Â V, respectively.

The memory switching is a consequence of a phase transition in the material from the amorphous to the crystalline state [42]. The films of thickness 310, 465 and 781Â nm show resistances of the order of several MÎ© before switching. Since the films are deposited at room temperature and no further heat treatment followed, the initial state of the prepared films is amorphous (high-resistivity OFF state) in nature. Initially, a small amount of current is applied and with that there is an increase in voltage. When the voltage reaches the threshold/switching voltage (â10.13Â V) (Fig.Â 7a), the current is found to increase drastically due to switching. During switching, the electrical resistivity of the device is drastically reduced (several ohms) as the charge-defect states are fully filled by the field-injected charge carriers. With the sudden increase in current after the initiation of switching, there is large adiabatic Joule heating which suddenly raises the temperature at the electrode and causes the material to crystallize [43, 44], setting the film permanently in the ON state [43].

In the present GeS2 thin films, it may be reasonable to assume that the role of thermal processes is extensive and is responsible for the memory switching. As mentioned earlier, with the increase in film thickness, aÂ reorganization in the glassy network takes place and more heteropolar bond formation may occur making the network highly ordered. This could be a reason for the observed change in the switching voltages. This observation is consistent with the variation in Tauc parameter and Urbach energy, which suggests the formation of heteropolar bonds with increase in thickness.

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: GeS2 thin films were thermally evaporated on glass substrates. The effect of thickness on the switching phenomenon, Tauc parameter, Urbach energy, band gap and thermal diffusivity has been studied. The band gap energies were estimated and found to decrease with increase in film thickness. The width of the Urbach energy was determined and related to the disorder in the prepared films. The width of the Urbach energy was found to decrease with increase in film thickness, which indicates that the higher thickness films are more ordered. The prepared films are found to exhibit memory-type electrical switching behaviour.
